awd_titl_txt: RUI: Stochastic Interactions: Understanding Invasion and Extinction in Ecological Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop mathematical and statistical approaches to understand how environmental disturbances or invading species affect communities connected in large food webs. Biological systems are very complex, involving a multitude of interactions among many components at different scales.  How ecological communities may be grouped to explain how they coexist and evolve has been a subject of intense interest among biologists and ecologists.  Even after a century of research, the mathematical tools and models needed to fully understand observed species invasions and extinctions do not exist. Moreover, very few ecological studies have considered mathematical models with random effects.  Real world systems are inherently noisy, and only by including random effects can one properly understand an ecological community. The work involves collaboration with ecologists based at British Antarctic Survey in the United Kingdom to create an interdisciplinary approach grounded in specific data. The outcome of the research will be disseminated through seminars, presentations at meetings, and publications in peer-reviewed journals.  The project will train undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary mathematical research. Many students at Montclair State University are members of underrepresented groups in STEM (including women and minorities), and the research program will leverage existing programs which support these students. 

The project involves the use of theoretical, statistical, and computational approaches to improve our understanding of how models of large ecological systems respond to stochastic interactions and perturbations. Of particular interest is the study of primary and secondary extinction cascades in food webs as well as the susceptibility of food webs to invasive species. By considering a variety of empirical and synthetic food webs and incorporating full dynamics with stochasticity, the work will shed light on which ecosystem mechanisms (e.g., self-regulation, interaction strengths, feedback loops) serve to stabilize food webs against perturbations. The three major components of the work are to: (i) perform comprehensive numerical studies of the stochastic systems to improve our understanding of stochastic invasion, primary extinction, and the resulting secondary extinction cascade; (ii) develop new approaches using continuous Markov chain models to find the optimal path to extinction when considering pairwise, three-way, and higher-order interactions between species; and (iii) determine the vulnerability of an existing food web to invasion by exotic species using innovative asymptotic analysis  The results will be useful in improving our understanding of biodiversity and the organization of living communities as well as factors that can stabilize or destabilize ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project involved the theoretical, numerical, and statistical study of complex ecological systems. In particular, the project concentrated on the fundamental and challenging problem of stability of trophic food webs with respect to the nonlinear and stochastic dynamics that one finds in real ecosystems. Important outcomes from the project include:

Primary and Secondary Extinction Cascades: We considered the cascade, niche and generalized cascade models as a framework to generate synthetic food webs that exhibit a realistic ecological structure. We introduced dynamics, prescribed by the Lotka-Volterra equations, to our model-based networks in order to predict the behavior of the food webs under deterministic dynamics. Taken together, the models provide an explanation of structural and dynamical properties of food webs that are necessary to perform a mathematical analysis of response to perturbations such as extinction.

Noise-induced Extinction: Using synthetic and empirical food webs which are stable under deterministic Lotka-Volterra dynamics, we introduced demographic stochasticity to see the role of noise in the food web system. For very large populations, one sees the abundances of species fluctuate around the deterministically stable fixed point for very long times, with rare extinctions. However, as abundances drop, the risk of extinction can dramatically increase. Our studies enable one to measure species abundances and be able to predict how vulnerable individual species are to extinction as well as what components of a food web are vulnerable to collapse. By understanding the relationships between the food web topology, underlying deterministic dynamics, and demographic stochasticity, one can make accurate predictions about future extinction events. 

Control of Secondary Extinctions: After a primary extinction occurs, it is possible for other species to go extinct in a secondary extinction cascade. We investigated the effects of a control on a secondary extinction cascade triggered by a noise-induced extinction, and showed that the forced removal of a nonbasal species (a species which preys upon other species) immediately after a primary extinction can extend the mean time to extinction of individual nonbasal species as well as that of the complete extinction cascade. 

Efficiency, Extinction Order, and Predictive Machine Learning:  Using the connectance properties of the cascade model, we showed how trophic efficiency produces systems which are not persistent. With clustering analysis we showed how inequalities of the summed values of the birth, death, self-regulation and interaction strengths provide insight into which food webs are more enduring or stable. We developed a random forest model and a neural network model, both of which are able to predict the number of extinctions that would occur without the need to simulate the dynamics. We also determined which variables play the dominant role in determining the order in which species go extinct.

Seasonal Effects on Soil Food Webs: We considered a soil food web model and determined how seasonal variation in producer and detrital quality affects microbial nutrient cycling and the feedback to primary production. Our model enables one to quantitatively understand the tipping points between bacterially or fungally dominated decomposer communities, and more generally, the complex relationships between microbial decomposers, primary production, and nutrient cycling.

Matrix Scaling and Tipping Points: To assess which ecosystems are most vulnerable it is necessary to compare the resilience of complex interaction networks in a meaningful way. We considered two methods that have previously been developed to deal with populations with widely different time scales and which contain differing self-regulation terms. We showed the relation between the leading eigenvalue of one method with  the critical self-regulation (tipping point) of the second method. This work has wider implications in network theory and linear algebra.

Controlling Extinction Using Early Warning Signals: We considered a dynamical system where the noise induces a transition from the deterministically stable state to the extinct state. We developed a method whereby metric-based indicators from early warning signals theory are used to determine when the system is in a weakened state. By applying a control during a weakened state, the system can go extinct earlier than it otherwise would without control. We showed that applying a control at the wrong time (during a highly resilient state) can lead to a longer extinction time than if no control had been applied. 

The results obtained from these studies form the basis for improved understanding of how environmental disturbances affect food web communities. The results deepen our insight into the role of biodiversity and the organization of living communities as well as factors that can stabilize or destabilize ecosystems. Outcomes from the research project were presented at conferences and seminars, and were published in refereed scientific journals including Theoretical Ecology, SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems, and International Journal of Dynamics and Control.

The project supported two undergraduate students, three masters students, and a PhD student. All students were members of groups under-represented in the STEM disciplines.
